description.narrative: Consortium project led by NRC and in partnership with Ana Aqra and Amel Association. In response to the needs of children, parents/caregivers, teachers, schools, and school communities, the consortium will address the immediate and mid-term needs of all community-level stakeholders to support student retention and improve quality of teaching and learning. To ensure a rapid response at the onset of the project as well as identifying and strengthening existing systems at the school-community level, the consortium will implement the project in three phases: Phase I: Immediate response and needs-based programmatic development (Jan 2021 - June 2021) Phase II: Community-informed response (July 2021 - June 2023) Phase III: Community-led response with support from consortium partners (June 2023 - March 2024) Alert leads on the integration of social cohesion in the community school framework and on capitalisation.
NRC - lead Ana Aqra Amel Association

Objective 1: Supporting student retention directly. Academic and psychosocial interventions to address students’ needs, explicit support to their parents/caregivers, and teacher professional development on how to address the needs of under-performing students. Objective 2: Strengthening teacher capacity. Teacher professional development to support teachers’ knowledge and skills to contribute to social cohesion, active learning, and psychosocial support (in school and online). Objective 3: Increasing access to school and enhancing social cohesion. Community-informed and/or led interventions to improving the school environment and addressing critical needs including school rehabilitation, community-led initiatives, community referrals, and meaningful exchanges between groups to cultivate understanding and enhance social cohesion. Objective 4: Learning for capitalisation modelling. The compilation of data and evidence of the interventions and project learning activities to inform programmatic adaptions and sustainable transfer of successful interventions to school communities, duty-bearers, and external actors.

The project will support 10 public schools over three years in the most vulnerable cadastres or affected by the Beirut Port explosions, and where partners have strong relationships with the communities. 31,000 students
